awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award Grant: Study of Satellite Radio Resource Management by Differential Game Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at the home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Claflin University has potential broader impacts in a number of areas. The goal of this project is to study optimal control strategy in satellite communication system to allocate power among competing user terminals, who share a frequency-selective interference channel, and would be competing for limited radio resources; as well as to enhance teaching and learning at the university by involving undergraduate students in mathematical modeling. 

Differential game (DG) models will be used to solve for optimal control strategies, because of special features of the system - competitive and dynamical. The major components of this dynamic game are as follows: In a frequency-selective Gaussian interference channel model, there are K transmitters and K receivers in the system. Each transmitter and receiver pair will be viewed as a user or a player. The whole frequency band is divided into N frequency bins. In frequency bin f, player k allocates power in a pattern of some function, which is referred to as player k's control. With this control, if treating interference as noise, the data rate player k can achieve at time t is a function of time. Player k's objective is to maximize the data gain in a specific period of time interval, which is an integration of the data rate function over this time interval. The dynamics of the system is the rate of change of channel gain, which is a function of controls and noises. Thus, all players are combined in a same dynamic system, using their controls to realize their own data needs. Under the assumption of nonexistence of collaboration between players, a non-cooperative differential game model will be constructed to solve for optimal power allocation strategy for each player. Furthermore, cooperative and hierarchical competition models will also be studied for different types of competition. Mathematical analysis will be conducted to analyze the optimality condition of DG models. Numerical methods will be developed to solve models.  The broader impacts of the project will be to directly supply satellite communication controllers with a power allocation strategy design, and to generalize solution methods developed for solving DG models and improve applicability of differential game models.  This project will be conducted in collaboration with the Institute for Mathematics and its Applications at the University of Minnesota.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-RIA award supported the PI in collaborating with John M. Cioffi, Professor of Electrical Engineering at Stanford University, to complete the investigation of optimal strategies for satellite communication subsystems to allocate power among competing user terminals. It also supported ten African American students in conducting research under the PI's supervision, with the ultimate goal of increasing the graduation rate in mathematics at Claflin University (CU) and better preparing underrepresented minorities for more advanced studies or careers in STEM upon graduation. This was achieved through a comprehensive hands-on research experience with requested high-performance computing instrumentation and modern mathematics software.

Project outcomes addressing the intellectual merit are as follows:

1. A Cooperative Game model has been developed for multiple user terminals existing in a satellite transponder's communication channel. These terminals share a frequency-selective Gaussian interference channel and compete for limited radio resources to meet their individual data rates. The game model has been analyzed and solved analytically and numerically using the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions. The solution of this model provides a set of rules based on channel cross-coupling gain and Noise Power Ratio, enabling the centralized control of a transponder to select either FDMA or Frequency Sharing as the optimal power allocation strategy. This scheme is more accurate and applicable than existing methods and is characterized as a straightforward two-step process.

2. A non-cooperative Differential Game (DG) model has been introduced to study competition within a transponder's communication channel. The optimality condition of Nash Equilibrium (NE) for the DG model is derived as a system of Differential Algebraic Equations (DAE). An iterative algorithm designed to minimize all users' Hamiltonians has been developed to solve the DAE system. The numerical solution of the NE provides the transponder's power control system with each user's power-control strategy at equilibrium.

3. Due to Stackelberg competition among asymmetrical users in a transponder's channel, where some users (leaders) have priority in choosing their power control strategy, while other users (followers) must optimize their strategy based on the leaders' choices, a Stackelberg Differential Game (SDG) model has been set up. The optimality condition for the Stackelberg equilibrium involves a set of DAEs with embedded control strategies from the counterpart group. An iterative algorithm that optimizes the Hamiltonians of both leaders and followers has been developed to solve for the Stackelberg equilibrium. The numerical solution of the SDG model provides the transponder's power control system with each user's power-control strategy at the Stackelberg equilibrium.

The broader impacts of this project are significant and multifaceted, encompassing advancements in academic collaboration, student research opportunities, educational development, and technological innovation:

1. Academic Collaboration and Institutional Development: The RIA award facilitated the Principal Investigator's (PI) collaboration with Professor John M. Cioffi at Stanford University. This collaboration has established a long-term relationship between them. Such a partnership enhances CU's research capabilities and teaching quality in applied mathematics, fostering long-term institutional growth.

2. Student Research and Publications: The RIA award supported ten African American students to engage in research under the PI's supervision. These students had the opportunity to publish theses or papers, contributing to the academic community and gaining valuable research experience.

3. Support for Minority and First-Generation Students in STEM: CU has a student body that is over 90% African American, with 60% being first-generation college students. The university plays a crucial role in the regional and national efforts to recruit minority students into advanced STEM degrees. By integrating the project's research into two project-based lab courses at the undergraduate level, the project engages about ten African American and first-generation students per semester in cutting-edge mathematics research.

4. Technological Advancements in Satellite Communication: The research has broad implications for satellite communication, providing more general, accurate, and applicable power allocation schemes for satellite transponders through game models, enhancing the overall efficiency and functionality of satellite communication subsystems. The solution methods derived from the project improve the applicability of DG models.

These outcomes demonstrate the project's substantial contributions to academic growth, student development, and technological innovation, particularly in supporting underrepresented groups in STEM and advancing satellite communication technologies.
